Not having hitherto observed these secondary fringes, ex-
cept where they proceeded from intersections of premaries; 
it was concluded that this was the only cause of their 
appearance; but, by this last experiment, I was convinced 
of the error of this opinion, & that they are entitled to the 
same rank of originality as primary fringes or Newtonian 
rings; & since they are always found divided into <u>two<\u> classes, 
I shall <s>hence<\s> henceforward venture to denominate them 
<u>Binaries<\u> which perhaps may not be an improper character-
istic for the whole genera, in contradistinction to <u>primaries<\u>, 
as it will appear in the sequel, that there are several 
species of the former, & at least two of the latter. 
16 Ex. <s>24<\s> This experiment was made to ascertain whether 
two slips of glass only, when the uppermost was pressed by its own 
weight alone would produce Binary fringes between them; 
& I succeeded in perceiving one set whose breadths were about 
one tenth of an inch each, see fig. 9 these are best seen by clear 
Day light; but it is also necessary to have a piece of black 
velvet under the lower slip, otherwise to have its under 
side painted black. 
17 Ex. <s>25<\s>. In endeavouring to see these fringes mentioned in last 
article by candle light I was disappointed, but accidentally perceived others of 
a different species, less in breadth, but much more numerous, & 
by which the whole length & breadth of the glass slips were 
covered. these were visible by the light of a small candle 
only, nor could they be perceived except in the image 
of the Blaze of the candle reflected from the upper sur-
face of the upper slip of glass, & by moveing either the 
eye, or the candle, or the slips across the direction in which 
the fringes appeared. & even with every precaution I 
sometimes fail[e]d in seeing them, which I attributed to 
the presence of very minute dust between the glass 
plates, which in some cases can be known only by its 
effects. moreover, when the Eye changes from a greater to a less 
quantity of light, it requires some time to adapt itself 
to such delicate & minute objects, before it can perceive them 
satisfactorily
